notes: Purine + 2 benzenes. Code's FusedRing made fused pair countable. SMILES compressed purine into c1c2...c12.
Benzodifuran. SMILES compressed 3 fused rings; Haiku undercounted. Code listed all 3 rings in FusedRing.
Coumarin-furan tricyclic. Same pattern — SMILES compressed heterocyclic fusions.
Purine + benzene. Simple case. Code overcounted — .fuse() of 2 rings double-counted.
Same molecule as #4 but with code+relabel. Relabeling fixed the overcounting — Haiku named fragments (pyrimidineRing, imidazoleRing, benzeneRing) and counted correctly.
SMILES: misidentified fused pyrimidine-benzene as benzimidazole. Code explicitly showed diaminopyrimidine.fuse(benzene) making quinazoline obvious.
Code hallucinated amine and ester from Fragment('NC') and Fragment('CO') fragments seen in isolation.
Both representations failed on this complex ergot alkaloid. Neither helped identify it correctly. Too complex for Haiku regardless of representation.
3 fused rings but only 1 aromatic — other 2 have OCC (non-aromatic). Code made this explicit: Fragment('c1cc(ccc1)') vs Fragment('c2cOCC2'). SMILES mixed case hard to parse.

truth: bis-indolyl uracil (two indole rings connected via pyrimidinedione)
notes: Code explicitly showed indole.fuse(benzene) x2 + pyrimidinedione. SMILES compressed into unreadable c1...c2...c34 notation. Code decomposition revealed building blocks.

SMILES wins. Stereocenters are marked with @/@@ in SMILES, trivial to count. Code fragments still contain [C@H] SMILES notation internally — no structural advantage. Code agent hallucinated wildly (1425).

Peptide chain. SMILES made Haiku double-count NH donors (12 vs 7). Code laid out backbone with explicit NH positions + 6 separate Linear(['O'],['=']) carbonyls as countable units. Code perfect, SMILES donors way off.

smiles_answer: imidazole (correct but rambling, initially said benzimidazole)
code_answer: imidazole (correct, crisp, identified all 3 substituents clearly)
notes: Both correct on scaffold ID. But code answer was more structured — named each building block (benzoic acid, imidazole, pyridine, methylenedioxyphenyl). SMILES answer rambled and initially confused benzimidazole before self-correcting.
SMILES wins. C(=O)N pattern trivially countable in SMILES. Code split the carbonyl (Linear) away from backbone N, making it hard to trace which C=O are amide vs carboxyl.

smiles_answer: correct — all 4 rings identified with correct sizes and aromaticity
code_answer: correct — all 4 rings identified with correct sizes and aromaticity
notes: Tie. Both nailed it. Code made ring names more explicit but SMILES was also clear since ring atoms are inline.
